title: Chris Packham contacts I'm A Celeb 'every year' about use of animals
text:
James McVey and Nick Knowles take part in a Bushtucker Trial on the show last year (Picture: Rex/Shutterstock)

Chris Packham writes to I’m A Celebrity…Get Me Out Of Here! bosses ‘every year’ about their use of animals on the show.

I’m A Celeb is known for its bushtucker trials, which often involve celebrities being doused in or dining on insects.

The Springwatch presenter is keen to talk to show bosses about how they include animals in the future, accusing them of ‘stereotyping’ snakes and cockroaches and ‘using these animals for entertainment’.

He told Metro.co.uk: ‘The time I spend making TV programmes I’m trying to engender an affinity for life. It’s not just about the cute and the cuddly, it’s about everything because everything is necessary. So it’s about snakes it’s about spiders, it’s about cockroaches.

‘What I object to on the programme is the ongoing stereotyping of these animals as being things which are dirty, disgusting, poisonous dangerous and so on and so forth. And that’s counter productive to everything that I do.

‘We don’t have wild animals in the circus any more, we don’t like animals being used for that sort of entertainment any more. So why would we countenance it on a TV programme?

‘I plan to write them another letter saying, “can I come and talk to you, can we come up with a solution whereby your programme is no less entertaining and popular and you don’t stereotype and abuse animals?”.’

Chris Packham has contacted the show ‘every year’ about the use of animals (Picture: Lia Toby/WireImage)

He previously publicly blasted the ITV reality show for ‘abusing animals’ at the TV Choice Awards last month.

The 2015 series was hit with 1000 complaints after Ferne McCann ate a live spider during the final.

Chris, 58, is fronting the Smart Energy GB campaign to explore the vital role that energy efficiency can play in protecting the environment.

The campaign aims to help people become more energy efficient by installing a smart meter.

Chris feels that people shouldn’t rely on politicians to solve the issue of energy efficient.

‘As much as we need government action here I think we need to figure out how to do things ourselves. A lot of people are aware of the climate problems and want to do something but they’ve got to be empowered to do it, and this one of the simplest things,’ he explained.

‘A lot of people think that if we’re gonna achieve our carbon zero by 2050 or 2025 as Extinction Rebellion are demanding, we’ll have to live in a cave and chew carrot. That isn’t the case.

‘I’m excited by the fact we’ve got these new technologies that will allow us to maintain the quality of our lives and improve it while addressing this really very serious issue.’

Chris Packham is raising awareness of the #missingpiece and encouraging everyone to act by getting a smart meter installed.
